title: How to Make Crispier Bacon

steps.headline: Thaw your bacon.
steps.description: Partially frozen or overly cold bacon will take longer to cook and be harder to crisp. Thaw your bacon completely before cooking. If your bacon is frozen, move it to the fridge the night before you plan to cook.

steps.headline: Bring the bacon to room temperature.
steps.description: After thawing your bacon and before you start to cook it, leave it out on your kitchen counter for five to ten minutes. Allowing your bacon to come up to room temperature will make the fat easier to render, providing you with crispier strips once you are ready to cook.

steps.headline: Flour your meat before cooking.
steps.description: Prior to cooking, sprinkle a small amount of flour on both sides of your bacon. You shouldn’t need more than a couple of tablespoons per package, depending upon how thick your strips are cut. Dust off any excess, and fry in a pan or cook in the oven. The flour absorbs grease and keeps the bacon from curling on itself, which allows it to get evenly crispy when cooking.

steps.headline: Start with a cold skillet.
steps.description: The key to crispy bacon is letting the fat render out. Starting your bacon off in a hot pan cooks it before that can happen. Don’t turn your stovetop on until you have already laid out your bacon. Then, turn it on to a medium low temperature and cook until crispy. If you are in a rush, use a cast iron skillet. Even when started cold and used on the same temperature, cast iron tends to cook bacon faster than a standard pan.

steps.headline: Add a splash of cold water to the pan.
steps.description: Before you turn on the heat, add just enough water to cover the bottom of your pan. Then, cook your bacon on a medium high heat until all the water has evaporated. Turn the heat down to a medium low and keep cooking until your bacon is crisp. The water renders the fat, so there is less splattering and more even cooking. Your bacon will be crisp and just a little tender, ideal to crumble for salads and baked potatoes.

steps.headline: Turn your bacon frequently.
steps.description: Turning your bacon in the pan promotes more even cooking and discourages curling. Turn your bacon once every two to three minutes until it is done. Typically, crispy bacon takes 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Drain the grease.
steps.description: Grease tends to pool in the bottom of the pan when you skillet-fry bacon. If the grease gets to the point where it starts covering the bacon strips, carefully drain it directly from the pan into a can or disposable receptacle and continue cooking.

steps.headline: Bake it in the oven.
steps.description: Many bacon enthusiasts will tell you this is the way to go to get a perfectly crisp strip. Preheat your oven to 400° F (204° C) and bake your bacon to your desired level of crispy. Generally, this will take around 15 minutes. To get even crispier bacon, place a wire cooling rack on the baking sheet and lay your bacon on top. This lets the fat and grease drip down and keeps the bacon extra crispy.

steps.headline: Pop bacon in the microwave.
steps.description: Microwave bacon is convenient, especially when you only want a few strips. To get it crispy, lay two paper towels down on a plate, then lay out your bacon strips. Make sure they don’t overlap. Then, cover the strips with two more paper towels and microwave on high for two to three minutes. If your bacon isn’t as crispy as you want it, keep microwaving in 30 second increments until it’s just right. Do not press the paper towels into the bacon. This will cause  the two to stick together and result in paper-covered bacon.

steps.headline: Make bacon bits in a stock pot.
steps.description: Smaller bits of bacon get crispy quickly. Cut your bacon strips perpendicularly and throw the small chunks into a stock pot. Turn the stove on to a medium heat and allow the bacon to cook for several minutes, stirring with a long spoon occasionally. After ten or so minutes, use a slotted spoon to scoop the bacon out of the grease.
